front.div:
Abstract
We present the first empirical study of fast-flux service
networks (FFSNs), a newly emerging and still not widely-
known phenomenon in the Internet. FFSNs employ DNS
to establish a proxy network on compromised machines
through which illegal online services can be hosted with
very high availability. Through our measurements we show
that the threat which FFSNs pose is significant: FFSNs oc-
cur on a worldwide scale and already host a substantial
percentage of online scams. Based on analysis of the prin-
ciples of FFSNs, we develop a metric with which FFSNs can
be effectively detected. Considering our detection technique
we also discuss possible mitigation strategies.
